Description: Scarab in Egyptian blue, probably mould-made; underside decorated with schematic representation of a lion ready to attack an ibex from behind, both facing right; motif likely incised.
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Gardner (in Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 6). This scarab produced in the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming) belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially found in Cartage, Cumae and Perachora (Gorton 1996, 114-117, type XXXII, subtype A28-35, see especially A28 for this specimen). A second scarab, 1888,0601.56, manufactured in glazed composition and also discovered in Naukratis, presents a similar scene (Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 7). Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 115-116, Type XXXII A28)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.13) (phase 3)
